author: Kendall Ashman
title: Homeland Security and Wilson County Sheriffâ€™s Office educate parents about online risks
text:
WKRN articles Homeland Security and Wilson County Sheriffâ€™s Office educate parents about online risks Kendall Ashman Thu, December 5, 2024 at 10:50 PM UTC 2 min read
WILSON COUNTY, Tenn. (WKRN) â€” Enough is enough. That is the message the Wilson County Sheriffâ€™s Office and Homeland Security are sharing with parents Thursday night. This comes after the sheriffâ€™s office received reports of sextortion cases, as well as a handful of school threats made on social media this school year.
In September, the Wilson County Sheriffâ€™s Office responded to one school threat after the other.
â€œThe whole month of September there were 18 threats. Then I look at our stats last month and we had one,â€ said Scott Moore, Wilson County Sheriffâ€™s Office Captain.
ðŸ“§ Have breaking news come to you: Subscribe to News 2 email alerts â†’
News 2 asked Captain Moore how many of the 18 threats in September were made on social media. â€œI would say at least three out of every four,â€ Moore said.
Advertisement Advertisement Advertisement Itâ€™s a trend seen here in Middle Tennessee and across the country.
In September, one Mt. Juliet middle school student was taken into custody after a school threat was spread on TikTok. At Barry Tatum Academy, a student was charged with threats of mass violence and two counts of false reports after a bomb threat was made.
â€œWhenever we have a school threat, we utilize so many resources. Itâ€™s not just the SRO, it involves the detective division and Homeland Security,â€ Moore said.
In response, Homeland Security created an initiative called Project iGuardian to raise awareness about the risks for minors on social media and prevent them from falling victim to tactics used by online predators.
Advertisement Advertisement â€œOne of the things and weâ€™ve had cases here in Wilson County involving sextortion and itâ€™s a real problem rising across the country,â€ Moore said.
â© Read todayâ€™s top stories on wkrn.com
On Thursday, the Wilson County Sheriffâ€™s Office and Homeland Security want to start a conversation with parents so they can be more aware of online dangers.
â€œAs parents at home we need to have talks with them and tell them this is why this is important and not be involved or start communication or send pictures like this itâ€™s something we donâ€™t preach enough,â€ Moore said.
The meeting is being held at the Wilson County Board of Education from 6-8 p.m.

author: Business Today Editorial
title: OpenAI Revenue Doubles To US$12 Billion Annualised As Funding Talks Advance
text:
OpenAI has nearly doubled its annualised revenue to US$12 billion in the first seven months of 2025, according to The Information, which cited a source familiar with the matter. The figure suggests the Microsoft-backed firm is generating about US$1 billion a month, with ChatGPT products reportedly drawing around 700 million weekly active users across consumer and business segments.
Reuters said it could not immediately verify the report, while OpenAI declined to comment.
The report added that OpenAI has raised its projected cash burn for 2025 to about US$8 billion, an increase of US$1 billion from earlier estimates.
Meanwhile, the company is lining up investors for the second tranche of its US$30 billion funding round, with shareholders Sequoia Capital and Tiger Global Management expected to invest hundreds of millions of dollars. Investors, including Japanâ€™s SoftBank, are reportedly close to securing US$7.5 billion in commitments for this phase.
SoftBankâ€™s total agreed investment in OpenAI has reached US$32 billion since its initial backing in late 2024.
